Posted: September 13, 2014
												This is really some of the most fun I have had with an Adventure game in a long time. It has a lot of great humor, the puzzles actually make sense, and the story is actually interesting and fun. There is minimal "pixel hunting" for items to pick up or interact with, which is nice. You get to play as more than one character eventually, and you switch control between them in real time as you see fit in order to solve some of the problems facing you. Overall I ran into really no bugs or technical issues so the experience was always fun and enjoyable. If you're looking for a good laugh, this is a great choice, especially if you snag it on sale like I did.Edit: As of writing this, I am 7 hours into the game (not even half way complete), and I am wholeheartedly recommending it. Fun times all around.

Posted: September 19, 2014
												Highly recommend.  Overall the game is beautiful and a lot of fun.  The references to gaming, specific RPGs and well-known movies/books in the medieval/wizarding vein are well-done, very funny and make a great game even more enjoyable.  IThe voice acting is great and the character interactions are very entertaining.  All of the puzzles and problem-solving in the game are interesting and require a bit of thinking, but none so difficult or convoluted that you'll be stuck for more than a few minutes wandering from map to map wondering what miniscule item you missed in a shadow like in some other point and clicks. My only criticism is that the game seems to end fairly abruptly.  The story building and problem-solving are fantastic up to the last chapter or so, then it all goes extremely quickly and the ending seems ever-so-slightly out-of-place, imo.  Still a great game, I absolutely loved it.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												It is a very nice, little adventure and I can recommend it.The puzzles are quite easy in comparison to other classic adventures. The developers deicided to present you only with the items and interactions which are relevant at the point of story. Which helps a lot. You still need to search the screen like in many other of these games, though. Removing interactions after done or viewed (mostly twice) was also a very good choice from the developer.The story is okay and plays with many fantasy clich√™s mixed up with trinkets/ideas from our reality. If you don't like fantasy, you probably shouldn't play it. In the end of the story I even liked all of the characters, despite some of them make it really hard at first.The end (final confrontation) of the game is a bit too short for my taste. It seemed rushed to me. I am not sure if the money ran out or the writing was not fleshed out, but it doesn't make it necessarily a bad game.Overall the game is not too long, so you can easily play it through in multiple sessions. Like in most of the adventure games there is also no replay value.One technical issues I had: I played the game in a very high resolution (3440x1440), so for some puzzles (like the map and the dance puzzle) I couldn't see the part I needed to see. As workaround I set the resolution to a lower value in these instances.

Posted: May 25, 2014
Short AswerShould I buy it - For $20 it does give you a good bit of game for the price. YesShould I buy it on sale - YesLong AnswerThe Book of Unwritten tales is a beautiful, albeit prerendered, 3D point and click game set in a dungeons and dragons type fantasy world (Gnomes, goblins and such). It really is just a little more than a standard P and C. It does not hold your hand but it does lead you a little bit. It has a nice little cast of quirky characters and a quaint storyline (The little guy gets to save the world, etc.) but it doesnt break any new walls for the genre. It did give me a few chuckles at times and overall I did find this game to be enjoyable. It does have the small draw back of all P and C in that there is no replayability (once you solve a puzzle it stops being a puzzle.) Total play time will vary from 6 to 14 hours depending on puzzle skills but if you like P and C or if you can get it on sale then this would be a good addition to your library.

												This is a solid point'n'click adventure game, with lots of jokes and pop culture references. The puzzles are not too hard, and you can press the spacebar to see all the interactable objects on the screen. Posted: October 27, 2014
												One of the best point and click adventures I've played in a long time. I have avoided The Adventure Company games in the past because their puzzles used to require the character in the game to perform enough actions to "reason out" the solution to the puzzle you were working on, and I usually had the solution sorted well before that, but would not be allowed to combine the items to solve the puzzle until I spoke to the appropriate person that the character needed to in order to reason it out themselves. Combining challenging puzzles with a plot is a difficult task, and since LucasArts stopped making point and click adventures, very few companies have been able to do this well. The Book of Unwritten Tales was excellent start to finish, with an absolutely BRILLIANT final chapter. The only criticism I have is that some of the items you can interact with are very difficult to notice, and sometimes you need to interact with them several times before you get what you need out of them (like a box you need to check twice in order to get both items, but the character gives no indication that it contained anything else the first time you check). Pressing SPACE to highlight the interactable items on screen helps this, but to me it feels like a spoiler to do this. I got this game as a gift, and wouldn't have bought it myself, because I had so little faith in the publisher, but they really won it back with this one.

Posted: September 28, 2014
												What should I say about The Book of Unwritten Tales?Let's start with all the positive things.Everything.Okay, almost. The game is more than I expected it to be. I really liked the characters and story, the world, the atmosphere, the style, the soundtrack and the system. Much love was put into the game, more than in TellTales games, I'd say. It is a worthy addition to the genre.That being said, let's talk about the negative stuff. There really isn't much negative going on here, though.1. The game is way too easy. Most riddles are no-brainers, you often realize a solution to the riddles before you even have to solve it. Many things are already clear by simply looking at the scene. Only in rare cases you need to stop for a bit and to think the riddle over.2. The game is way too short. The end came a bit... surprisingly abrupt. I expected another 4 or so chapters at least.Nonetheless, in the end I felt sad that my adventure is already over. And that is what counts the most.The game felt right, so I can only recommend it. Just don't expect anything challenging.Yours sincerely,a pointy and clicky demonsword.

Posted: December 24, 2012
												This game is a mouse-driven point and click adventure game full of puzzles that harkens back to the grand old days of gaming in the early 1990's when graphics and special effects weren't available to enhance a game.  In all there are about 150 puzzles and some 200 items that can be picked up and combined to make other items that are useful in the game.During the game you will play the role of each of four characters shifting back and forth between each one.  Character dialog has a lot of self-aware humor that pokes fun at traditional RPG games and which frequently makes reference to other adventure RPG games and many movies.  So don't be surprised at Star Wars references or at seeing a little Temple of Doom in one scene.  All in all it is pretty clever and full of wit.The graphics are beautiful and the storyline is fairly interesting.  The characters are enjoyable and the fantasy setting is pretty neat.  Although it is very linear, that doesn't spoil the game.  Each scenario has a little bit of fun to it whether its game play or something that just makes you chuckle.  The Book of Unwritten Tales should give you about 20 hours of enjoyment.  If you have played a lot of games, this one will be all the more enjoyable because you will get all the slings and barbs in the dialog. It can be a fun romp when you are tired of more serious games and just want something silly.

Posted: January 27, 2014
												Beautiful art, great voice acting, and fun puzzles help this little point and click adventure along.  It is frequently funny with some subtle and not so subtle pop culture references.  I found it somewhat short, but well worth the price for the laughter.  The only part that was really frustrating was the potion making task (start at 3 o'clock, trust me, it helps).  The story was somewhat predictable, but the twist in the last chapter was rather nice.  There are also sections where you have to switch off between party members to accomplish a task or puzzle.  All in all, I recommend it, and I'm looking forward to working on the prequel game that was released, "The Book of Unwritten Tales: Critter Chronicles".

Posted: February 2, 2015
												Just finished the game.  It's fun.  Simple puzzles that don't require huge leaps in logic, and few enough options that a "Click on everything" mentality should pull you through.  Everything looks nice, the characters are likable enough.  You need to be able to enjoy a good dose of meta-humor though, this game knows it's woorld doesn't make sense, but instead of trying to hide it like other point and clicks it laughs with you at it's sillyness.  Example: I enjoyed one part when the question was posed "Why do you want to go there?" and the answer was "To look at everything one at a time then pick up anything I can, since it'll probably come in handy later." The falseness of the world is a feature, not a bug.That said, I picked it up on sale.  I enjoyed the heck out of it, but I honestly wouldn't put down $20 on this game.  It's funny, but not challenging enough to occupy you, and not long enough for me to pay full value, that's just me though.  If you've got some money to spend and it goes on sale again I definately reccomend it.

Posted: January 31, 2015
												I was surprised by how much I loved this game.  A lot of fantasy-themed point-and-click adventure games fall flat, but this one is great.  Certain tasks require you to switch between your snooty elf, your good-natured gnome, and your sarcastic human party members, which is a nice twist on the genre. The story itself isn't too remarkable, but it makes up for it with tongue-in-cheek pop culture references (Lord of the Rings, adventure games in general, D&D, etc) and really goofy puzzles that are just challenging enough to keep you interested but not to frustrate.

Posted: February 13, 2015
												The Book of Unwritten Tales is a nice point-and-click adventure told around  the intertwining stories of characters that act by more or less chosen disposition in the background of a war the outcome of which they must play a mayor role in. Along the way they have to become artillery, mages, tomb raiders, a level 98 blacksmith and more all the while not taking themselves to seriously and referencing again and again (to just name a few) Tolkien, Star Wars, Indiana Jones, Psycho, Mission Impossible and commenting on specific adventures and adventures in general.There is nothing the game really excels in and it has a few irritating aspects. Still it is mostly fun and I'd recommend playing this adventure over a number of others. For example, by nature of a light fantasy setting versus a thriller setting this game has a a story less deep than Cognition but is more fun and I dare say the better experience.+ Good voice acting and music+ Good story with a nice conclusion+ Atmospheric items0 Believable, yet sometimes irritating character traits- A few minor bugs- One tedious sort of riddle- One riddle I consider brokenImportant hints:The spacebar is your friend. It will highlight all the hotspots on the screen and helped me find a few important hotspots I might have otherwise overlooked for quite some time.The disk puzzle is broken for me. Be aware, the shaft through the disks becomes a button once all disks are stacked. To the best of my knowledge: The puzzle is supposed to work like Mastermind showing colour-coded evaluations of the current "centre column" on the stacked-up disks - red for wrong symbol, yellow for wrong disk but right symbol, green for right disk and right symbol. I don't know whether the position of colours has meaning. The evaluation is executed whenever the button (former shaft) is activated (or you leave and reenter the puzzle screen). The button must also be pressed in order to finally solve the puzzle and make the machine work.Now, I spent something between one and three hours trying different approaches and characters and looking around for clues because not every evaluation with four green spinners is a solution that makes the machine work. I still do not know how to solve the puzzle. My last approach was to get all green spinners, then have as few spinners as possible spin on evaluation.The "tedious sort of riddle" involved running around branching paths in the earth pixie mine and being thrown back to the start again and again which started to get annoying after about the fourth time. I'm guessing the throw-backs can be avoided but when you come up to them it's not directly clear how.I liked the atmospheric items, i.e. hotspots in new rooms that the character comments on once or twice - thus adding to the scenery - and which are then deactivated as hotspots thus not cluttering up the screen.The voice acting is good and together with nice music helps tell a story that half colours a fantasy world and half mocks adventure culture in a nice way, be it games or movies or books. The last part of the story offered a not quite unexpected twist where my only question was "will I play that or will that be played for me" as the game had simply told me about the happening of an episode twice before. Anyway, with that twist the game comes to an, and let me state here I value that highly, agreeable conclusion.I had a few minor graphical bugs not really worth explaining. I had one state bug where the character was moved from A to B within a sequence but returned to A after which was clearly not the intention and almost a problem. Nate swims up to the ladder in the sunken temple when the chamber fills with water. After the sequence he was back in the chamber - standing, not swimming, in the water. Walking around a bit with another character helped.I can easily recommend The Book of Unwritten Tales and I'm looking forward to the second game which I'm about to start right now.

Posted: September 28, 2014
												What should I say about The Book of Unwritten Tales?Let's start with all the positive things.Everything.Okay, almost. The game is more than I expected it to be. I really liked the characters and story, the world, the atmosphere, the style, the soundtrack and the system. Much love was put into the game, more than in TellTales games, I'd say. It is a worthy addition to the genre.That being said, let's talk about the negative stuff. There really isn't much negative going on here, though.1. The game is way too easy. Most riddles are no-brainers, you often realize a solution to the riddles before you even have to solve it. Many things are already clear by simply looking at the scene. Only in rare cases you need to stop for a bit and to think the riddle over.2. The game is way too short. The end came a bit... surprisingly abrupt. I expected another 4 or so chapters at least.Nonetheless, in the end I felt sad that my adventure is already over. And that is what counts the most.The game felt right, so I can only recommend it. Just don't expect anything challenging.Yours sincerely,a pointy and clicky demonsword.

Posted: May 25, 2014
Short AswerShould I buy it - For $20 it does give you a good bit of game for the price. YesShould I buy it on sale - YesLong AnswerThe Book of Unwritten tales is a beautiful, albeit prerendered, 3D point and click game set in a dungeons and dragons type fantasy world (Gnomes, goblins and such). It really is just a little more than a standard P and C. It does not hold your hand but it does lead you a little bit. It has a nice little cast of quirky characters and a quaint storyline (The little guy gets to save the world, etc.) but it doesnt break any new walls for the genre. It did give me a few chuckles at times and overall I did find this game to be enjoyable. It does have the small draw back of all P and C in that there is no replayability (once you solve a puzzle it stops being a puzzle.) Total play time will vary from 6 to 14 hours depending on puzzle skills but if you like P and C or if you can get it on sale then this would be a good addition to your library.

												Just finished the game.  It's fun.  Simple puzzles that don't require huge leaps in logic, and few enough options that a "Click on everything" mentality should pull you through.  Everything looks nice, the characters are likable enough.  You need to be able to enjoy a good dose of meta-humor though, this game knows it's woorld doesn't make sense, but instead of trying to hide it like other point and clicks it laughs with you at it's sillyness.  Example: I enjoyed one part when the question was posed "Why do you want to go there?" and the answer was "To look at everything one at a time then pick up anything I can, since it'll probably come in handy later." The falseness of the world is a feature, not a bug.That said, I picked it up on sale.  I enjoyed the heck out of it, but I honestly wouldn't put down $20 on this game.  It's funny, but not challenging enough to occupy you, and not long enough for me to pay full value, that's just me though.  If you've got some money to spend and it goes on sale again I definately reccomend it.

Posted: March 28, 2015
												The Book Of Unwritten Tales, or BOUT, is a funny, and fun game. I've never been much for point and click adventure games but I decided to give this one a try and I'm glad I did. Note that the game can be difficult, I had to use a guide several times.Pros: -Amazing music (I recommend getting the digital deluxe edition which includes the soundtrack)- Beautiful and imaginative scenery (which is good since you'll be staring at it A LOT)- References to many pop culture things, like Lord of the RIngs, Harry Potter- Lovable, and funny characters- I like the plot, the game is very light-hearted, so if you're expecting a kinda silly (but well-thought out) story, it keeps you interested in the gist of why you are figuring out puzzles and such.Cons:- Sometimes I got stumped and had to look up a guide only to find out that what I was looking for was right before my eyes, just very small and very hard to notice. Which isn't fun really. But that only happened a couple times.-Not really anything else.Overall I loved BOUT and would recommend it to anyone looking for a point and click adventure game

Posted: March 26, 2015
												Just finished this wonderful gem of a game, it has a few problems but overall was one of the funniest adventure games I have played in ages, it is very self aware and pokes fun at adventure game tropes as well as rpg tropes. Below I will list some pros and cons to the game as well as my final score out of 10. so lets get startedPROS1. The graphics- for a small adventure game I thought the graphics were outstanding especailly the backgrounds, there are also certain characters who look great, such as the minotaur in chapter 4.2. the voice acting- the va work in the game is for the most part amazing espcially wilbur, for the most part all the voice actors get into their roles and you can tell are having a blast playing these zany characters.3. Length- I was actually shocked this game was so long my play time says 15 hrs but is actually longer bc I played the demo first to see if I liked the game. So when I purchased the full game I sped through the demo parts that I had already beaten.4 Dialogue- the Dialogue is pretty great, I would say a good 80 percent of the jokes land, and there were more than a few times I laughed out loud.5. Difficulty- as adventure games go this one is good for beginners, there a few brain teasers but for the most part the game is pretty easy, especially if you use the spacebar (the spacebar highlights all interactive hotspots on the screen). I reccomend using the spacebar bc I hate pixel hunting, I play adventure games for the story, characters, and puzzles not to pixel huntCONS1. Story- while the characters and dialogue are great and worth a play through, the actual story is pretty dull and boring and like most I found the ending to be a let down2. chapter 4- the game is broken up into 5 chapters and while I dont hate chapter 4, I felt like it dragged and the game lost some steam here, bc for the most part you only play as nate, and he was my least favorite character, he grew on me but I never felt attached to him like I did to Ivo and Wilbur.3. Pixel Hunting- if you dont want to use the spacebar than pixel hunting is real bad, bc a lot of the objects blend into the background and they are hard to see.4. MINI GAMES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!- this is an adventure game yet the devs decided to include two mandatory mini games that just plain suck, especailly the dancing one, in you guessed it chapter 4 lol.CLOSING COMMENTS AND SCOREOverall I loved this game, it has fun characters, a decent story, and can be laugh out loud funny. It is a long game if you take ya time and explore the different dialogue options, I got it on sale on steam for 5 dollars, I cant wait to play the new one now I highly reccomend this game to adventure game fans or for gamers who are interested in the adventure game genre, bc its good for beginners. final score is8.5/10

Posted: October 27, 2014
												One of the best point and click adventures I've played in a long time. I have avoided The Adventure Company games in the past because their puzzles used to require the character in the game to perform enough actions to "reason out" the solution to the puzzle you were working on, and I usually had the solution sorted well before that, but would not be allowed to combine the items to solve the puzzle until I spoke to the appropriate person that the character needed to in order to reason it out themselves. Combining challenging puzzles with a plot is a difficult task, and since LucasArts stopped making point and click adventures, very few companies have been able to do this well. The Book of Unwritten Tales was excellent start to finish, with an absolutely BRILLIANT final chapter. The only criticism I have is that some of the items you can interact with are very difficult to notice, and sometimes you need to interact with them several times before you get what you need out of them (like a box you need to check twice in order to get both items, but the character gives no indication that it contained anything else the first time you check). Pressing SPACE to highlight the interactable items on screen helps this, but to me it feels like a spoiler to do this. I got this game as a gift, and wouldn't have bought it myself, because I had so little faith in the publisher, but they really won it back with this one.

Posted: July 26, 2015
												A lovely adventure game somewhat betrayed by its simplicity.Throughout the course of the game you gain control of 3 characters (you can maybe count it as 4 even), playing some sections exclusively as one character, or sometimes getting the option of switching to another. All three are fun to play and have their own distinct personalities which also translate into their observations of the world, which you can directly see by inspecting the same items with different characters. Although the last one you are introduced to does take a little while to like, since at the beginning he's quite obnoxious.The story is one of the most important parts in an adventure game, and here it certainly does not disappoint. It is a lighthearted save the world plot spanning through a diverse set of areas with a real feeling of adventure. However the ending did feel rushed, and compared to the rest of the game the're just the feeling that not as much thought went into designing it.The biggest problem the game has is that there is only one usable button, you do absolutely everything with only the left mouse click. This means that even if you get stuck somewhere, it is not too difficult to brute force your way through, because there is a much more limited number of possibilities than in traditional adventure games.But perhaps there is some sort of an upshot to this as well. The game flow is rarely interrupted and you're not going to get frustrated over some random puzzle, although there is one particularly annoying area in a mine which for some reason uses a top down camera instead of the traditional sidescrolling one.The Book of Unwritten Tales is certainly lengthy enough without the need for convoluted puzzles, it took me 13 hours to finish it, but I didn't spend much of that time trying to figure out what to do next.7 / 10

Posted: February 13, 2015
												The Book of Unwritten Tales is a nice point-and-click adventure told around  the intertwining stories of characters that act by more or less chosen disposition in the background of a war the outcome of which they must play a mayor role in. Along the way they have to become artillery, mages, tomb raiders, a level 98 blacksmith and more all the while not taking themselves to seriously and referencing again and again (to just name a few) Tolkien, Star Wars, Indiana Jones, Psycho, Mission Impossible and commenting on specific adventures and adventures in general.There is nothing the game really excels in and it has a few irritating aspects. Still it is mostly fun and I'd recommend playing this adventure over a number of others. For example, by nature of a light fantasy setting versus a thriller setting this game has a a story less deep than Cognition but is more fun and I dare say the better experience.+ Good voice acting and music+ Good story with a nice conclusion+ Atmospheric items0 Believable, yet sometimes irritating character traits- A few minor bugs- One tedious sort of riddle- One riddle I consider brokenImportant hints:The spacebar is your friend. It will highlight all the hotspots on the screen and helped me find a few important hotspots I might have otherwise overlooked for quite some time.The disk puzzle is broken for me. Be aware, the shaft through the disks becomes a button once all disks are stacked. To the best of my knowledge: The puzzle is supposed to work like Mastermind showing colour-coded evaluations of the current "centre column" on the stacked-up disks - red for wrong symbol, yellow for wrong disk but right symbol, green for right disk and right symbol. I don't know whether the position of colours has meaning. The evaluation is executed whenever the button (former shaft) is activated (or you leave and reenter the puzzle screen). The button must also be pressed in order to finally solve the puzzle and make the machine work.Now, I spent something between one and three hours trying different approaches and characters and looking around for clues because not every evaluation with four green spinners is a solution that makes the machine work. I still do not know how to solve the puzzle. My last approach was to get all green spinners, then have as few spinners as possible spin on evaluation.The "tedious sort of riddle" involved running around branching paths in the earth pixie mine and being thrown back to the start again and again which started to get annoying after about the fourth time. I'm guessing the throw-backs can be avoided but when you come up to them it's not directly clear how.I liked the atmospheric items, i.e. hotspots in new rooms that the character comments on once or twice - thus adding to the scenery - and which are then deactivated as hotspots thus not cluttering up the screen.The voice acting is good and together with nice music helps tell a story that half colours a fantasy world and half mocks adventure culture in a nice way, be it games or movies or books. The last part of the story offered a not quite unexpected twist where my only question was "will I play that or will that be played for me" as the game had simply told me about the happening of an episode twice before. Anyway, with that twist the game comes to an, and let me state here I value that highly, agreeable conclusion.I had a few minor graphical bugs not really worth explaining. I had one state bug where the character was moved from A to B within a sequence but returned to A after which was clearly not the intention and almost a problem. Nate swims up to the ladder in the sunken temple when the chamber fills with water. After the sequence he was back in the chamber - standing, not swimming, in the water. Walking around a bit with another character helped.I can easily recommend The Book of Unwritten Tales and I'm looking forward to the second game which I'm about to start right now.

												I absolutely recommend this game! Any lover of point and click, story based game will have a ball playing this. It's challenging enough, but you can get by without a walkthrough if you really try. The story was fantastic, and the character development is fenominal. Posted: October 6, 2016
												A great, humorous point'n'click fantasy adventure that lets you play from the perspective of several different characters throughout the story. The intro is a little slow, but things soon ramp up as you solve the initial set of puzzles and the humour starts to shine through. If you've played any type of RPG or adventure game in the past, there are some great sequences poking fun at the genres, players and developers, lovely stuff. The humour doesn't always hit, there are some off screen sequences that don't quite come off, but its good to see a game try something a bit different. The artwork and style is lovely, although there are occasional glitches and not all animations fully reflect the actions that are taking place. But these are minor fiobles that don't detract from the main experience. The voice acting is generally top notch too, great to hear a Welsh accent from one of the main actors.The game is quite easy however. Items are easy to come by, sometimes just given to you when talking to other characters and experienced adventure game players will find themselves solving puzzles before knowing why they need to. This can lead to a bit of awkwardness, but that will be the player messing with the natural flow the developers had in mind.That said, at 17 hours playtime, the difficulty level is not too far off the mark and the Book of Unwritten Tales does not out stay its welcome at any point. A thumbs up from me and roll on the next adventure in the series..

Posted: May 16, 2016
												At the time of writing this game is ¬£17.99 full price. However I bought it on sale. I do not recommend this game at full price. It took me 12 hours to complete, using a walkthrough for one point. I found it a solid point and click adventure with a fun story, faintly amusing jokes and hat tips to other games/stories, and a mix of easy and difficult puzzles. The puzzles ranged from collecting things from different locations to figuring out how to sneak past things. There were no hidden object scenes and logic puzzles were very minimal.However, there are some hefty flaws.* As others have said, the characters move VERY slowly, so a lot of your time can just be sat watching them walk across the scene. * The puzzles are frequently in the form of "go to this place and get this thing then return to a previous place to get another thing and put them together, now go to a different place and give the thing to someone who will give you another thing and then..." which was wearing. I would have liked to see a wider mix, and as a seasoned point and clicker I was disappointed.* The ending baffled me with some odd time travel.

Posted: August 19, 2015
												This game was a delightful surprise to my collection of point-and-click games. I thought it'd be super cheesy (and it was at times) but it was enjoyable in that respect. Very funny, and I mean, as long as you like the strange meta feeling of a game that knows it's a game and much sarcasm. But beyond the funny, it's about thinking outside the box and it feels GREAT when you get something right. I hear myself saying often: "No way! WHAT?" and laughing about how silly the answer was. I must admit it's a bit difficult at points, especially if you missed an item, but otherwise the story is so engaging that those things are kind of a hit-and-miss for me. Please get this game, you won't regret it :)

Posted: September 12, 2014
												If you're looking for the best point-and-click adventure game ever you're probably not in the right place. If, however, you're looking for great writing, witty comebacks, funny characters and a mythical world that encompasses all things fantasy, my friend, you have just struck gold. TBoUT is like those olden "quest" games where you have to do chores for a billion different people before you actually get the one thing you are after. How it manages to keep from becoming repetitive and boring is its humour. It has jokes about a zillion different elements from geek culture ranging from Star Wars to WoW - the reason I'm not pointing them out is that I think they're better if you get them on your own, either on your first playthrough or your tenth. So happy hunting.

Posted: July 5, 2015
												My time with The Book of Unwritten tales is the most I've enjoyed playing an adventure game since the 90's. After playing Broken Age and not particularly enjoying it, I wondered if the genre simply no longer held any pull for me.  Well, it turns out Broken Age just isn't a very good game.BoUT's puzzles strike a nice balance of having a just enough old school adventure game obtuseness to them that the game doesn't feel trivial, yet they don't go to such ridiculous leaps of logic that they're frustrating either.Good puzzle design coupled with some very pretty visuals, voice acting that ranges from good to excellent, and a little bit of humor that works (and unfortunately a bit more that doesn't, but isn't intrusive) all make for a good game.

Posted: July 26, 2015
												A lovely adventure game somewhat betrayed by its simplicity.Throughout the course of the game you gain control of 3 characters (you can maybe count it as 4 even), playing some sections exclusively as one character, or sometimes getting the option of switching to another. All three are fun to play and have their own distinct personalities which also translate into their observations of the world, which you can directly see by inspecting the same items with different characters. Although the last one you are introduced to does take a little while to like, since at the beginning he's quite obnoxious.The story is one of the most important parts in an adventure game, and here it certainly does not disappoint. It is a lighthearted save the world plot spanning through a diverse set of areas with a real feeling of adventure. However the ending did feel rushed, and compared to the rest of the game the're just the feeling that not as much thought went into designing it.The biggest problem the game has is that there is only one usable button, you do absolutely everything with only the left mouse click. This means that even if you get stuck somewhere, it is not too difficult to brute force your way through, because there is a much more limited number of possibilities than in traditional adventure games.But perhaps there is some sort of an upshot to this as well. The game flow is rarely interrupted and you're not going to get frustrated over some random puzzle, although there is one particularly annoying area in a mine which for some reason uses a top down camera instead of the traditional sidescrolling one.The Book of Unwritten Tales is certainly lengthy enough without the need for convoluted puzzles, it took me 13 hours to finish it, but I didn't spend much of that time trying to figure out what to do next.7 / 10

												Quirky, clever and fun!  I really enjoyed playing it but it has glitches that the developers don't appear to be interested in providing patches for. I would highly recommend this game for all who love well crafted point & click adventures except for the developers home page forum being too glitchy to register - that's very bad attitude to paying customers IMO. Posted: March 5
												A well-designed PAC game. I enjoyed some of the innovation involved in switching characters (and just the change in perspective). I wasn't sure how I'd feel about the fact that you can only combine items if they'll work (no real need for experimentation), but I didn't mind it. I found it streamlined the game, but it took out some of the fun of trial and error (and seeing what the designers came up with in terms of character response). There is a similar feature where you can't just repeatedly click on items to observe them - usually after 2 observations, the item then becomes inactive if it's not intended to be used later. Again, the feature was kind of nice, but took away some of the challenge and fun of thinking outside the box. I tend to like at least a few trickier puzzles in a game that get me stuck for a while, but this game was relatively straightforward. It was fun, but not particularly challenging.
